title: Adsorption Isotherms of Water, Propan-2-ol, and Methylbenzene Vapors on Grade 03 Silica Gel, Sorbonorit 4 Activated Carbon, and HiSiv 3000 Zeolite
abstract: This work reports adsorption isotherms of water, propan-2-ol, and methylbenzene vapors on three commercial adsorbents: grade 03 silica gel, Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon, and HiSiv 3000 zeolite. The adsorption isotherms were measured at (293.15, 313.15, 333.15, 348.15, 373.15, 393.15, and 413.15) K and pressures up to 2340 Pa for water, 4460 Pa for propan-2-ol, and 2910 Pa for methylbenzene. Additionally measurements for the water vapor–Sorbonorit 4 system at (293.15, 303.15, 313.15, and 323.15) K and relative humidity up to 95% (at 323.15 K up to 70%) were made because of different type of adsorption isotherm. The measurements were carried out by intelligent gravimetric analyzer. The data obtained from measurements were correlated with selected multitemperature adsorption isotherms equations: Toth, Langmuir–Freundlich, and Dubinin–Astakhov.
text: The fast development of industry in the last few decades is main reason for the considerable growth of atmospheric air pollution. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are recognized as the most common group of polluting substances.
Pollution of the atmosphere by VOCs may have negative effects on the health of humans and animals as well as plants.
The harmfulness of VOCs was noticed by many governments which introduced regulations to limit VOC emissions into the atmosphere.
Adsorption processes are common ways to remove and recover VOCs from bulk gas streams.
The main advantages of the adsorption processes are low operation costs, even for very low VOCs concentrations (below 10
), and simplicity of the industrial adsorption systems.
An important problem during purifying of industrial gases is the presence of water vapor in almost all gas streams.
The presence of water vapor significantly influences the adsorption capacity of the adsorbents.
For modeling of the adsorption processes, the equilibrium data over a wide range of temperatures and pressures must be known.
The current state of the art modeling does not allow for the theoretical prediction of a single-component adsorption equilibrium.
Therefore, for each pair of adsorbate–adsorbent it is necessary to determine the experimental data.

In the literature, there is a large amount of data concerning the adsorption equilibrium of various pairs of adsorbate–adsorbent. However, the adsorption capacity of the adsorbents of the same type (for example, activated carbons) may vary significantly. Ye et al.

presented study on the adsorption equilibrium of propylene and ethylene on fifteen commercial activated carbons. Differences in the adsorption capacity of particular adsorbents were large, equaled approximately 300% between the lowest and the highest adsorption capacity.
Therefore, it is necessary to use equilibrium data for a particular adsorbent, not for the type.

This work presents data concerning adsorption equilibria of water and selected VOC (propan-2-ol and methylbenzene) vapors on three adsorbents: grade 03 silica gel, Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon, and HiSiv 3000 zeolite. Measurements were made by intelligent gravimetric analyzer (IGA). Three selected equilibrium models—Toth, Langmuir–Freundlich, and Dubinin-Astakhov—were fitted to experimental equilibrium data.

Three commercial adsorbents—grade 03 silica gel (Grace Davison, USA), Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon (Norit, The Netherlands), and HiSiv 3000 high silica zeolite (UOP, USA)—were used in this study. Table
shows the basic physical and chemical properties of the used adsorbents (data provided by manufacturer).
Table 1. Physical and Chemical Properties of Used Adsorbents
As adsorbate two VOCs (propan-2-ol and methylbenzene) and water were used. Table
provides information about the source and the purity of the chemicals used.

Studies of adsorption isotherms were carried out using the system IGA-002, Hiden Isochema (United Kingdom). Fully automated isothermal data acquisition, based on the static gravimetric method, guaranteed high accuracy. The main element of the IGA system is a precise microbalance with a resolution of 0.1 μg and an uncertainty of ± 1 μg.

An adsorbent was put in a stainless steel sieve, which was suspended to the balance by means of a gold chain and a tungsten wire. The sample mass was approximately 75 mg. The sample was placed in a metal reactor, which allowed an ultrahigh vacuum to be achieved. A circulating water bath GR 150 (Grant Instruments, United Kingdom) or electric furnace Cryofurnace (Hiden Isochema, United Kingdom) was used interchangeably as thermostat. The sample temperature was measured by a platinum resistance thermometer (Pt100), which was placed in the vicinity of the sample. The platinum resistance thermometer has a resolution of 0.01 K and uncertainty of ± 0.1 K. The pressure in the reactor was measured using the manometer with a resolution of 0.1 Pa and uncertainty of ± 0.3 % of measured value. The repeatability of isotherms is better than ± 1 %.

Uncertainty analysis of individual measurement (weight, temperature and pressure) leads to statement that the overall measurement uncertainty is very small. All measurement instruments in the IGA system were thermostatted what ensured very small uncertainty.
Before each measurement, the sample was outgassed “in situ” at 453.15 K under vacuum (10

Pa) for 2 h. This ultrahigh vacuum was achieved using a system of two vacuum pumps: diaphragm pump MD 1 (Vacuumbrand, Germany) and turbomolecular pump TMU 071 P (Pfiffer Vacuum Technology, Germany). After degassing, measurement was made for selected values of temperature and various pressures. Adsorbed compounds in the liquid phase was used as source of vapor, and was placed in thermostatted vessel at 328.15 K.

The IGA system based on measurements of pressure inside the chamber automatically controlled the input and output valves in order to achieve the set point of pressure. For the each set point of pressure and temperature the real time processor (RTP) enabled automatic recording of the changes in sample mass due to adsorption. The IGA system based on measurements of mass and the built-in algorithm of calculations enabled prediction of the asymptotic adsorption value. After reaching 99 % of the estimated mass value, the IGA system passed to the next point of isotherm (next the set point of pressure). Adsorption capacity was calculated from the equation
is the sample mass with adsorbed phase,
is the sample mass after degassing, and
is the molar mass of adsorbate
. The uncertainties of the adsorption capacity measurement were ± 0.00276 mol·kg
The measurement was carried out until all pressure set points were finished. Next, the sample was degassed, and measurements were made for next temperature.
To enable practical application of investigated adsorption isotherms, it must be presented in the form of mathematical equations.

To correlate equilibrium models with the experimental data, the multitemperature adsorption isotherm equations of Toth, Langmuir–Freundlich, and Dubinin–Astakhov were selected. More detailed description of used adsorption equilibrium models is available in the literature.

is the characteristic energy of adsorption for the standard substance (benzene). The affinity coefficient values for the used substances, calculated from definition, are 0.063, 0.860, and 1.253 for water vapor, propan-2-ol, and methylbenzene, respectively.
The parameters of selected equilibrium models were obtained by nonlinear regression using Statistica 10 (Statsoft).
The average relative error δ, which is a measure of model fitting accuracy to the experimental data, was calculated as follows:
is the calculated adsorption capacity, and
is the number of experimental points.

The experimental adsorption isotherms of nine adsorbate–adsorbent systems were obtained. The adsorption isotherms were measured at (293.15, 313.15, 333.15, 348.15, 373.15, 393.15, and 413.15) K and pressures up to 2340 Pa for water, 4460 Pa for propan-2-ol, and 2910 Pa for methylbenzene. Because of the specific nature of water adsorption on activated carbon, additional measurements were made at (293.15, 303.15, 313.15, and 323.15) K and relative humidity up to 95% (at 323.15 K up to 70%).
The equilibrium experimental data are shown in Tables

. The multitemperature adsorption isotherms—Toth, Langmuir–Freundlich, and Dubinin–Astakhov—were fitted to the experimental data. The obtained adsorption isotherms parameters and average relative errors are shown in Tables

Adsorption isotherms of water on grade 03 silica gel are mostly linear in the experimental range. Adsorption capacity is very high and at 293.15 K reaches 17.06 mol·kg
for 1880 Pa. When the the temperature increases, the adsorption capacity decreases rapidly, and at 313.15 K is 7.17 mol·kg
for 1880 Pa, while at 333.15 K is 2.65 mol·kg
for 1870 Pa. For higher temperatures, decreasing of the adsorption capacity is lower and at 413.15 K is 0.17 mol·kg

for 1870 Pa. It can be concluded that the silica gel is an excellent adsorbent for drying gas streams. The best fit to the experimental equilibrium data for water–grade 03 silica gel pair gives the Langmuir–Freundlich model, with a relative error of 19.22 %.

Adsorption isotherms of water vapor on Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon are type V of Brunauer classification. For the isotherms of this type, the highest impact has capillary condensation phenomenon, which occurs for the water relative humidity above 50 %. Basic measurements are presented in Table
additional data were presented for which better fitting was achieved. Adsorption capacity is significant, with a value of 20.4 mol·kg
for 2220 Pa. The Dubinin–Astakhov model best describes the data shown in Table
, with a relative error of 31.52 %. The Langmuir–Freundlich model best describes the data showed in Table

For remaining seven adsorbate–adsorbent pairs examined, adsorption isotherms are type I of Brunauer classification. The increase in temperature causes a decrease in the adsorption capacity. As may be seen, from the analysis of Figures

, the temperature dependence of adsorption capacity is more or less linear. For the adsorbate–adsorbent pairs propan-2-ol–grade 03, methylbenzene–grade 03, propan-2-ol–Sorbonorit 4, water–HiSiv 3000, propan-2-ol–HiSiv 3000, and methylbenzene–HiSiv 3000, the best fit to experimental data gave the Langmuir–Freundlich mode, with relative errors of 8.91 %, 10.31 %, 4.2 %, 11.35 %, 7.61 %, and 9.22 %, respectively. For the methylbenzene–Sorbonorit 4 pair, the most appropriate model was the Toth model, with a relative error of 5.06 %.

In the work, three equilibrium adsorption models—Toth, Langmuir–Freundlich, and Dubinin–Astakhov—were correlated with experimental data. The Toth equation had four adjustable parameters, the Langmuir–Freundlich equation had eight adjustable parameters, and the Dubinin–Astakhov equation had three adjustable parameters. Generally, the best fit gave Langmuria–Freundlich model, so it can be concluded that the number of parameters have a great impact on the fit quality. Toth and Dubinin–Astakhov models also showed a fairly good fit for most adsorbent–adsorbate pairs. In addition, the Toth equation can provide the heat of adsorption, and the Dubinin–Astakhov equation can provide the total micropore volume of the adsorbent.
the comparison of adsorption capacity for each component at 293.15 K were shown.

Figure 12. Comparison of adsorption capacity at 293.15 K of propan-2-ol on: +, grade 03silica gel; ○, Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon; □, HiSiv 3000 zeolite.
Figure 13. Comparison of adsorption capacity at 293.15 K of methylbenzene on: +, grade 03 silica gel; ○, Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon; □, HiSiv 3000 zeolite.

The obtained results indicate that Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon has the highest adsorption capacity for VOCs (propan-2-ol and methylbenzene). Grade 03 silica gel has highest adsorption capacity of water for lower pressures (up to 1700 Pa). For higher pressures (above 1700 Pa) Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon has the highest adsorption capacity.

The adsorption isotherms of water, propan-2-ol, and methylbenzene vapors on three commercial adsorbents, grade 03 silica gel, Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon, and HiSiv 3000 zeolite, were measured at (293.15, 313.15, 333.15, 348.15, 373.15, 393.15, and 413.15) K and pressures up to 2340 Pa for water, 4460 Pa for propan-2-ol, and 2910 Pa for methylbenzene. Additionally measurements for the water–Sorbonorit 4 system at (293.15, 303.15, 313.15, and 323.15) K and relative humidity up to 95% (at 323.15 K up to 70%) were also made. The selected equilibrium models, Toth, Langmuir–Freundlich, and Dubinin–Astakhov, were correlated with the experimental equilibrium data. The computed average relative errors of models fitting to experimental data proved that good agreement was attained for VOC adsorption onto examined adsorbents. Also fairly good agreement was stated for water adsorption.

The experimental and computed data obtained in this study can be used for modeling of cyclic adsorption processes (for example, temperature swing adsorption (TSA), pressure swing adsorption (PSA), and pressure and temperature swing adsorption (PTSA)). It also can be the basis for modeling of the multicomponent adsorption equilibrium using interpolative models.

Adsorption equilibria of butan-1-ol, toluene and water vapour onto Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon and the co-adsorption of organic compounds and water vapour onto SKT activated carbon
Adsorption equilibria of butan-1-ol, toluene and water vapour onto Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon and the co-adsorption of organic compounds and water vapour onto SKT activated carbon

The results of both exptl. and theor. studies are presented.  The results of exptl. studies of adsorption equil. for the pure components butan-1-ol, toluene and water vapor onto Sorbonorit 4 activated carbon are 1st reported, with measurements having been undertaken using a dynamic gravimetric method.  The results for butan-1-ol and toluene were correlated using the Langmuir, Freundlich, Redlich-Peterson, Toth and Dubinin-Astakhov models, while the results for water vapor were correlated using the equations of Dubinin and Serpinsky and of Barton and Barton and co-workers.  A simple model enabling the prediction of the adsorption equil. of butan-1-ol/water vapor and toluene/water vapor mixts. on SKT activated carbon is then presented.  Such predictions were made from data for the pure components, with the equil. data for both pure components and mixts. being taken from the literature.  The model, which is simple to simulate and verify using exptl. data, is based on the Polanyi theory and the Dubinin-Astakhov isotherm equation.  With this model, fairly good agreement was obsd. between predicted and exptl. binary mixt. adsorption data for the systems examd.

Adsorption of Propylene and Ethylene on 15 Activated Carbons
Adsorption of Propylene and Ethylene on 15 Activated Carbons
Ye, Pengcheng; Fang, Zhaohua; Su, Baogen; Xing, Huabin; Yang, Yiwen; Su, Yun; Ren, Qilong

The adsorption equil. of propylene and ethylene on 15 com. activated carbons at 101.3 kPa and 313 K were studied.  The adsorption amt. of propylene and ethylene on these adsorbents varied greatly from a min. of 1.593 mmol/g-1 for propylene and 1.430 mmol/g-1 for ethylene to a max. of 4.528 mmol/g-1 for propylene and 3.100 mmol/g-1 for ethylene.  Characteristics of these activated carbon adsorbents such as the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, micropore area, external surface area, total pore vol., micropore vol., and av. pore diam. were detd. by a volumetric method.  The adsorption amt. of the two alkenes on these 15 carbon samples were correlated with their phys. parameters.  Both the BET surface area and micropore vol. have an effect on their adsorption.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
, and Ar on High Silica Zeolites
Adsorption Equilibria of CO2, CH4, N2, O2, and Ar on High Silica Zeolites
Bao, Zongbi; Yu, Liang; Dou, Tao; Gong, Yanjun; Zhang, Qing; Ren, Qilong; Lu, Xiuyang; Deng, Shuguang

Adsorption equil. of CO2, CH4, N2, O2, and Ar were detd. on three lab-synthesized ZSM-5 adsorbents and four com. available high silica zeolites including HiSiv-3000, HSZ-980HOA, HSZ-890HOA, and HSZ-390HUA.  The synthesized ZSM-5 samples have a similar pore textural property (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore vol.) as that of HiSiv-3000.  The BET surface areas and total pore vol. of the ZSM-5 sample are ∼300 m2 g-1 and 0.2 cm3 g-1, resp.  The synthesized materials have relatively higher adsorption capacities than those of HiSiv-3000 for the gases studied.  The order of adsorption capacities of CO2, CH4, N2, Ar, and O2 on each high silica zeolite follows the order of their polarizabilities.  The selectivities of N2/O2 and Ar/O2 pairs are ∼1.0, suggesting that it is very difficult to sep. them by equil.-based adsorption processes.  HSZ-890HOA and synthesized DT-100 showed higher equil. selectivities for CO2 over N2 and CH4, implying that they are potential adsorbents for CO2 sepn. from flue gases as well as landfill gases.

Diffusion Measurements of Isopentane, 1-Hexene, Cyclohexene in Polyethylene Particles by the Intelligent Gravimetric Analyzer
Diffusion measurements of isopentane, 1-hexene, cyclohexane in polyethylene particles by the intelligent gravimetric analyzer
Chen, Meijuan; Wang, Jingdai; Jiang, Binbo; Yang, Yongrong

The diffusion coeffs. of isopentane (i-C5H12), 1-hexene (C6H12), cyclohexane (C6H14) in polyethylene particles were measured by a highly sensible microbalance-intelligent gravimetric analyzer, using the desorption method with N2 as a bypassing gas.  Both the effective diffusion coeffs. (Deff) and dil. diffusion coeffs. (D∼eff) were measured simultaneously.  ∼eff Was about one magnitude smaller than Deff and the logarithmic form of D∼eff was linear with that of Deff.  In addn., the effects of particle size and distribution, polymer properties (e.g., the crystallinity and melt index), and operating conditions (e.g., temp. and pressure) on Deff were systematically studied.  Deff increased linearly with the increase of the square of particle size.  The diffusion behaviors of hydrocarbons in polyethylene are of great importance in the polymn. and purging processes.  © 2010 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J. Appl. Polym. Sci., 2012.
Adsorption of Gases and Vapors on Carbon Molecular Sieves
Adsorption of Gases and Vapors on Carbon Molecular Sieves
O'koye, I. P.; Benham, M.; Thomas, K. M.

The adsorption phenomena of oxygen and nitrogen on a carbon mol. sieve were studied above the crit. temp. of the adsorptives as a function of pressure in order to understand further the mechanism of air sepn.  The uptake of both gases studied was virtually linear at low equil. pressures, in agreement with Henry's law, but deviation occurred at higher pressures.  The adsorption kinetics were studied with different amts. of preadsorbed gas for changes in pressure of 11 kPa and partial pressure in helium of ∼10 kPa.  The gas adsorption kinetics obey a linear driving force mass transfer model.  The ratios of the rate consts. (kO2/kN2) for each pressure increment were 35-43 for pure gases and 21-27 for gas/helium mixts., and these ratios clearly demonstrate the mol. sieving characteristics.  The presence of water vapor is detrimental to the operation of carbon mol. sieves.  The adsorption and desorption characteristics of water vapor with different amts. of preadsorbed water were studied for comparison with oxygen and nitrogen adsorption over the pressure range 0-1.8 kPa for pressure steps of 0.1 kPa.  The results are discussed in terms of the mechanism of gas sepn. using carbon mol. sieves.

The Potential Theory of Adsorption of Gases and Vapors for Adsorbents with Energetically Nonuniform Surfaces
The potential theory of adsorption of gases and vapors for adsorbents with energetically nonuniform surfaces

A survey of the results of exptl. and theoretical studies that have led to the development of the potential theory of adsorption in which the detg. role is played by dispersion forces.  The views developed are applicable to the phys. adsorption of gases and vapors on small-pore active carbon and on carbon black.  They are important also for other adsorbent-adsorbate systems in which dispersion forces are the dominant component of adsorption.  14 references.
